Cerebral Vasculitis after Meningitis Meningitis from pneumococcus (a type of bacteria) often causes serious brain damage and inflammation in the blood vessels. A new study looked at 21 patients who had meningitis to see if they developed this problem called cerebral vasculitis. The study found that: - Cerebral vasculitis happens in about 14% of people with pneumococcal meningitis. - There is no connection between the type of bacteria and whether someone develops cerebral vasculitis. - People who get cerebral vasculitis have higher levels of certain proteins in their cerebrospinal fluid that are linked to inflammation and brain damage. - These patients had worse outcomes than those without cerebral vasculitis, even though none died from it. This study suggests that cerebral vasculitis might be a complication of pneumococcal meningitis and could lead to worse results. More research is needed to understand if the levels of certain proteins in the cerebrospinal fluid can predict who will develop this problem.


Abstract

Cerebrovascular complications are frequent in pneumococcal meningitis and are associated with poor functional outcomes. Among these complications, the incidence of cerebral vasculitis (CV) has been increasingly reported, but neither its pathogenesis nor its relationship with cortisone treatment have been conclusively established. We wanted to describe cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) metalloprotease (MMP) levels, which are linked to cerebral damage and vasculitis (MMP-2, MMP-9, and the antagonist TIMP-1), and differences in microbiological serotypes or virulence factors that could be associated to the development of this complication. A prospective multicenter cohort study was performed from January 2019 to August 2022. All adult patients diagnosed with pneumococcal meningitis and for whom CSF samples from the initial lumbar puncture were available were included and followed up for six months after discharge.Streptococcus pneumoniaestrains isolated from CSF or blood were assessed including whole genome sequencing and CSF levels of MMP-2, MMP-9, and TIMP-1 were measured. CV developed in three of 21 patients (14.3%). The serotypes of those who developed CV were 3, 9¬†N, and 35¬†F, with no microbiological differences with respect to the non-CV group. The CV group had higher CSF levels of MMP-9 (13.2 vs. 9.8 ng/L) and TIMP-1 (699 vs. 318 ng/L), but lower CSF levels of MMP-2 (5689 vs. 10,484 ng/L) compared with the non-CV group. Although no patients with CV died, they had worse clinical outcomes than the non-CV group. CV is a frequent complication of pneumococcal meningitis that may be associated with worse outcomes. No differences in microbiological serotypes or virulence factors were detected. Further analyses should be carried out to confirm whether CSF MMP levels may be markers of CV development.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-99883-z



2025-05-05 ü§ñ Using a common cold bacterium to grow a part of the SARS virus.

Title

Escherichia coliNissle 1917 efficiently expresses the RBD domain of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein without codon optimization


ü§ñ Abstract

Here is a simplified version of the abstract: Scientists have found a new way to make a special kind of medicine called a vaccine that can help fight the coronavirus. They used tiny parts of a bacteria called Escherichia coli to create a vaccine. The bacteria was made to stick out proteins on its surface that can trigger an immune response. These proteins are very good at attracting the body's natural defense system, making them a great tool for creating a vaccine. This new method is promising because it uses a safe and proven strain of bacteria that has already been tested in humans.


Abstract

Bacterial outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) represent a promising and versatile platform for vaccine delivery. Their inherent self-adjuvant properties and the ability to be adorned with a wide range of heterogeneous antigens position them as a powerful tool in the fight against infectious diseases.Escherichia coliNissle 1917 (EcN) stands out as a highly valuable probiotic strain because of its long history of safe use and proven clinical benefits in humans. The EcN strain was genetically engineered to derive OMVs displaying receptor binding domain (RBD) of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein on their surface. Although some research groups have previously expressed the SARS-CoV-2 viral spike protein or the RBD inE. coli, particularly in EcN, this study shows a maiden effort to utilize the gene encoding native RBD. The probiotic EcN exhibited a significant level of native RBD expression, demonstrating a more efficient codon usage pattern compared to commonly used bacterial expression systems such as BL21, and DH5Œ±. EcN was engineered to display the native form of viral RBD on the surface using the Lpp-OmpA system. Cell fractionation studies clearly indicated the presence of RBD in the membrane fraction. OMVs displaying RBD on their surface were isolated using ultracentrifugation and the presence of RBD in the OMVs was confirmed by western blot followed by immunofluorescence analyses. Due to their preferential uptake by antigen presenting cells, OMVs derived from EcN bearing native form of RBD hold promise as a potential COVID-19 vaccine candidate.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-99902-z



2025-05-05 ü§ñ How COVID-19 Cases Affect Mortality Rates During the First Pandemic Surge

Title

Revisiting the link between COVID-19 incidence and infection fatality rate during the first pandemic wave


ü§ñ Abstract

Many people who got COVID-19 during the first big outbreak were more likely to die from it if they lived in places with very high infection rates. Researchers wanted to know why this was happening. They looked at 82,000 DNA test results from across France and found that in areas with super-high infection rates, people over 60 were getting infected much more often than those under 60. They also found that the number of deaths from COVID-19 increased by a lot when the infection rate went up. The researchers think that's because older people are getting sick more often, not just because hospitals got overwhelmed.


Abstract

Several studies found an association between COVID-19 incidence, cumulated over the first pandemic wave, and the risk of death for infected individuals. They attributed this association to hospital overload. We studied this association across the French departments using 82,467 serological samples and a hierarchical Bayesian model with spatial smoothing. In high-incidence areas, we hypothesized that hospital overload would increase infection fatality rate (IFR) without increasing infection hospitalization rate (IHR). The analyses were adjusted for intensive care beds per capita, age of the population, and diabetes prevalence (as a surrogate for obesity). We found that increasing departmental incidence from 3 to 9% rose IFR from 0.42 to 1.14% (difference 0.72%, 95% CI 0.49‚Äì1.01%), and IHR from 1.66 to 3.61% (difference 1.94%, 95% CI 1.18‚Äì2.80%). An increase in incidence from 6 to 12% in people under 60 was associated with an increased proportion of people over 60 among those infected, from 11.6 to 17.4% (difference 5.8%, 95% CI 2.9‚Äì8.8%). Higher incidence increased the risk of death for infected individuals and their risk of hospitalization by the same magnitude. These findings could be explained by a higher age among infected individuals in high-incidence areas, rather by than hospital overload.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-99078-6



2025-05-05 ü§ñ Boosting immune system against malaria at a specific stage using nanoparticles that show parts of the malaria parasite's protective protein.

Title

Elicitation of liver-stage immunity by nanoparticle immunogens displayingP. falciparumCSP-derived antigens


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version: Malaria is still a big problem around the world. Even though we have made some progress in fighting it, there's still work to be done. We've developed new vaccine ideas by using different parts of the malaria parasite that don't work as well with our current vaccines. To make better vaccines, we looked at over 100 new options and tested them on a large scale. What we found out is that adding certain parts of the parasite can help make the vaccines more stable and stronger. We also learned which ideas to stop exploring because they didn't work. Our research helps us understand how to create better vaccines that will protect people from malaria for longer.


Abstract

A vaccine that provides robust, durable protection against malaria remains a global health priority. Although a breakthrough in the fight against malaria has recently been achieved by the licensure of two vaccines based on the circumsporozoite protein (CSP), the effectiveness and durability of protection can still be improved. Both vaccines contain a portion of CSP that does not include epitopes targeted by recently identified, potently protective monoclonal antibodies, suggesting that newer immunogens can expand the breadth of immunity and potentially increase protection. Here we explored >100 alternative CSP-based immunogens and evaluated the immunogenicity and protection of a large number of candidates, comparing several to the licensed R21 vaccine. The data highlight several general features that improve the stability and immunogenicity of CSP-based vaccines, such as inclusion of the C-terminal domain and high-density display on protein nanoparticle scaffolds. We also identify antigen design strategies that do not warrant further exploration, such as synthetic repeat regions that include non-native repeat cadences. The benchmark R21 vaccine outperformed our best immunogen for immunogenicity and protection. Overall, our data provide valuable insights on the inclusion of junctional region epitopes that will guide the development of potent and durable vaccines against malaria.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41541-025-01140-x



2025-05-05 ü§ñ Understanding the Immune System of People Who Had COVID-19 but Are Not Vaccinated

Title

Multi-layered deep immune profiling, SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia and inflammation in unvaccinated COVID-19 individuals with persistent symptoms


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version of the abstract: People who got very sick from COVID-19 are more likely to have lingering symptoms for a long time. Researchers studied 48 people with severe COVID-19, comparing those who still had symptoms three months after getting sick (early persistent symptoms) to those who didn't. The study found that early persistent symptoms were linked to problems with the immune system, including fatigue, brain fog, and inflammation. However, the researchers didn't find a link between lingering symptoms and immune dysregulation. In other words, people who got COVID-19 are more likely to have lingering symptoms due to other factors, not just their immune system. The study suggests that further research is needed to understand what causes these lingering symptoms.


Abstract

BackgroundLong-COVID immunopathogenesis involves diverse factors. We longitudinally characterize hospitalized COVID-19 patients, examining the role of SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia and inflammation in immune dysregulation.MethodsHospitalized patients are evaluated during acute infection (T0), 3 months post-symptom onset (T1), and 3 years if symptoms persisted (T2). Immune profile includes characterization of SARS-CoV-2-specific/non-specific T/B cells (flow cytometry) and antibodies (ELISA, neutralization, ADCC). RNAemia and cytokines are quantified (RT-PCR, cytometric beads array) and correlated. Statistics: non-parametric cross-sectional, longitudinal and correlation analyses.ResultsHere we show 48 hospitalized individuals during acute COVID-19, 38 exhibit early persistent symptoms (EPS+) 3 months post-symptoms onset, 10 do not (EPS‚àí). Groups are comparable for age, sex, co-morbidities. The EPS+ shows fatigue, dyspnoea, anosmia/dysgeusia, diarrhea, chronic pain, mnestic disorders. Over time, they show a reduction of neutralization ability and total SARS-CoV-2-specific CD4 T cells, with increased total CD4 TEMRA, and failure to increase RBD-specific B cells and IgA+ MBCs. EPS+ patients show higher levels of T0-IFN-Œ≥‚Äâ+‚ÄâCD4 TEMRA, T1-IL-2‚Äâ+‚ÄâCD4 TEMand T1-TNF-Œ±‚Äâ+‚ÄâCD4 cTfh. In EPS+, baseline SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia positively correlates with CD4 TEMRA, follow-up SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia with ADCC. Among 38 EPS+ individuals at T1, 33 are evaluated 3 years after infection, 5 are lost at follow-up. 10/33 EPS+ show long-term symptoms (late persistent symptoms, EPS‚Äâ+‚ÄâLPS+), whereas 23/33 fully recover (EPS‚Äâ+‚ÄâLPS‚àí). Antibodies, RNAemia, and cytokines show no differences between/within groups at any time point.ConclusionsEarly persistent symptoms are associated with multi-layered SARS-CoV-2-specific/non-SARS-CoV-2-specific immune dysregulation. The shift towards non-Ag-specific TEMRAand ADCC trigger in EPS+ may relate to SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia. Early immune dysregulation does not associate with long-term persistent symptoms. Further research on SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia and early immune dysregulation is needed.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s43856-025-00832-8



2025-05-02 ü§ñ Okay, the user wants me to simplify the title so a regular person can understand. The original title is about cytokine, chemokine, and acute-phase protein profiles in plasma as correlative biomarkers of clinical outcomes for COVID-19 patients. First, I need to break down the key terms. Cytokine and chemokine are types of proteins involved in the immune response. Acute-phase proteins are those produced by the body during inflammation. Plasma is the liquid part of blood. Correlative biomarkers mean they relate to the clinical outcomes. So, the main points are: immune system markers in blood, and how they predict patient outcomes. The user wants it brief and clear, without any quotes or extra comments. Let me try to condense that. Maybe start with "Immune markers in blood" to cover the key components. Then mention they're linked to patient outcomes. Use simple words. "Predict patient outcomes" is straightforward. Combine the elements: "Immune markers in blood predict patient outcomes for COVID-19." Check if that's accurate. The original mentions cytokines, chemokines, and acute-phase proteins. Abstract

Coronavirus disease identified in 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome-coronavirus-2, had a global impact on human health and the economy. The aim of this study was to quantify cytokines, chemokines, and acute phase proteins in the plasma of patients with COVID-19 to elucidate potential biomarkers to inform prognostic and treatment decisions. Clustering analysis using the K-prototypes method identified underlying biological patterns in patients with COVID-19. The penalized multinomial logistic regression analysis identified two comorbidities (hypertension, congestive heart failure) and thirteen analytes as potential risk factors for COVID-19 progression with 88.2% accuracy. Based on a patient‚Äôs age, high concentrations of interleukin (IL)-6, monocyte chemoattractant protein-1, and pentraxin 3 were important biomarkers for lethal COVID-19. Decreased concentrations of interferon gamma-induced protein-10, IL-10, and soluble tumor necrosis factor receptor I were found to be associated with mild COVID-19, while increasing concentrations of these analytes could be used to predict COVID-19 severity.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-99248-6

CD55 upregulation in T cells of COVID-19 patients suppresses type-I interferon responses

Abstract

Complement overactivation, has been verified in COVID-19 patients. Complement regulatory proteins, including CD55, control complement overactivation thus eliminating complement deposition and cell lysis. We investigated complement regulatory protein expression in COVID-19 for potential deregulated expression patterns driving disease pathogenesis. Single-cell RNA-seq revealed increased PBMCsCD55expression in severely and critically ill patients. This increase was also detected upon integrated subclustering analysis of monocyte, T cell and B cell populations. FACS analysis confirmed the significant upregulation of CD55 expression in CD4+and CD8+T cells and monocyte populations of severely and critically ill COVID-19 patients. This upregulation was associated with decreased expression of type-I IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) in patients with severe and critical COVID-19, indicating a suppressor effect of CD55. Silencing ofCD55in T cells from COVID-19 severely ill patients in vitro and sensitization with SARS-CoV-2 peptides resulted in significantly augmented expression of ISGs and a reversal of their expression to levels similar to control or higher. The present study uncovers, to the best of our knowledge, a novel regulatory effect of CD55 on type-I IFN responses of severely ill COVID-19 patients, thus indicating its contribution to COVID-19 pathogenesis, and identifies a novel mechanistic pathway in the COVID-19 immune response.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s42003-025-08066-z

Title

ü§ñ Abstract

So, the main points are: antibody levels drop over time, especially in hospitalized people. Non-hospitalized people have higher anti-RBD antibodies. Anti-N levels drop quickly, but anti-RBD stays higher. Vaccines might help with anti-RBD. Also, older people have higher early antibodies but maybe not PASC or steroids. Mention the different antibody tests and the groups they studied. Then explain the results: higher antibodies in severe cases, but they fade over time. Hospitalized people have faster decline. Non-hospitalized have higher RBD antibodies. Anti-N drops quickly, but RBD stays. Vaccines help with RBD. Early antibodies correlate with age but not PASC or steroids. Need to include that. Make sure the simplified version is not too long and uses simple language. Avoid any markdown, just plain text. Keep it in one paragraph maybe, but split into two if needed. Let me put it all together. The study looked at how antibodies in people who had COVID-19 change over time. People with more severe illness had higher antibody levels initially, but these levels dropped quickly. Hospitalized people lost antibodies faster than those who weren‚Äôt sick. Non-hospitalized people had higher antibodies against a part of the virus called RBD, which helps fight severe infections. While antibodies against a protein in the virus (N) dropped quickly, antibodies against RBD stayed higher for 12 months, offering long-term protection. However, most people lost most of their initial antibody levels by 6 months. People who were hospitalized had higher initial antibody levels but lost them faster. Early antibody levels correlated with age but not with later symptoms or steroids. These findings show how antibodies in COVID-19 change and help explain why some people stay protected longer.


Abstract

BackgroundDefining the kinetics of SARS-CoV-2 antibody responses is critical for informing the management of reinfections, vaccinations, and therapeutics of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).MethodsUsing four antibody assays, we evaluated antibody titers against SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N), spike (S), and receptor binding domain (RBD) in 98 convalescent participants with varying COVID-19 disease severities (asymptomatic, mild, moderate or severe) at 1, 3, 6, and 12-months post-SARS-CoV-2-positive PCR¬†and in 17 non-vaccinated, non-infected controls.ResultsIncreasing acute COVID-19 disease severity correlates with higher anti-N and anti-RBD titers throughout 12 months post-infection. Anti-N and anti-RBD titers decline over time in all participants, except for increased anti-RBD titers post-vaccination, with hospitalized participants exhibiting faster decay rates. Less than 50% of participants retain anti-N titers above controls at 12 months, with non-hospitalized participants falling below controls sooner. Nearly all participants maintain anti-RBD titers above controls for 12 months, suggesting long-term protection against severe reinfections. Nonetheless, by 6 months, few participants retain >50% of their initial 1-month anti-N or anti-RBD titers. Notably, vaccine-induced anti-RBD titers are higher in non-hospitalized participants. Lastly, early convalescent titers correlate with age but not with Post-Acute Sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection (PASC) status or steroid use.ConclusionHospitalized participants initially¬†develop higher anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody titers¬†that decline faster relative to non-hospitalized participants. While anti-N titers fall below control levels in some participants, anti-RBD titers remain above controls over 12 months, demonstrating long-lived antibody responses known to protect against severe disease. These findings advance our understanding of COVID-19 antibody dynamics.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s43856-025-00828-4

Title

An intranasal subunit vaccine induces protective systemic and mucosal antibody immunity against respiratory viruses in mouse models


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, let's see. The user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. So, simplifying for a young person: Maybe start by saying that vaccines can be given in the nose instead of the arm. The albumin helps the vaccine get through the nose's lining. It works in mice and protects against viruses. Other vaccines don't do as well. So the conclusion is this nasal albumin vaccine is good for respiratory diseases. I need to avoid technical terms. Abstract

Although vaccines are usually given intramuscularly, the intranasal delivery route may lead to better mucosal protection and limit the spread of respiratory virus while easing administration and improving vaccine acceptance. The challenge, however, is to achieve delivery across the selective epithelial cell barrier. Here we report on a subunit vaccine platform, in which the antigen is genetically fused to albumin to facilitate FcRn-mediated transport across the mucosal barrier in the presence of adjuvant. Intranasal delivery in conventional and transgenic mouse models induces both systemic and mucosal antigen-specific antibody responses that protect against challenge with SARS-CoV-2 or influenza A. When benchmarked against an intramuscularly administered mRNA vaccine or an intranasally administered antigen fused to an alternative carrier of similar size, only the albumin-based intranasal vaccine yields robust mucosal IgA antibody responses. Our results thus suggest that this needle-free, albumin-based vaccine platform may be suited for vaccination against respiratory pathogens.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-59353-6

Title

SARS-CoV-2 variants retain high airborne transmissibility by different strategies


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, let's tackle this. The user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. First, I need to understand the main points of the original abstract. The abstract talks about how SARS-CoV-2 variants evolve to balance immune evasion and airborne transmission. It mentions hamsters testing different variants: Alpha, Delta, and Omicron. Each variant has different transmission properties. Alpha had lower viral particles but lower ID50, Delta had higher airborne emission but higher ID50. The fall in Delta's airborne emission correlated with lower infectivity and contagiousness. Omicron subvariants have varying transmission, linked to mutations in non-spike genes. Recombinant viruses with BA.1 or JN.1 spike and first-wave non-spike genes are more transmissible. The key takeaway is that different variants use different strategies to stay airborne, and knowing ID50 and viral load can help predict transmissibility. Now, simplifying this for a young person. I need to make sure the key points are there but in simpler terms. Avoid technical jargon. Use analogies if possible. For example, compare variants to different types of viruses that spread in the air. Mention the balance between hiding from the immune system and spreading. Use terms like "ID50" as is, but explain it briefly. Maybe say "the amount of virus needed to infect a certain number of animals." Check for clarity and brevity. Make sure the main findings are clear: different variants have different ways of spreading, and knowing how much virus they release can help predict how dangerous they are. Avoid any comments, just the simplified version. Ensure that the original meaning is retained without any markdown. Keep sentences short and straightforward. SARS-CoV-2 viruses change over time to stay strong against the immune system while still spreading through the air. In hamsters, different versions (like Alpha, Delta, and Omicron) spread better in the air. Some spread less but have fewer viruses (ID50), while others spread more but need more viruses to infect. Over time, Delta‚Äôs ability to spread via air decreases, even as it still spreads. Variants like Omicron have mixed effects, depending on how their genes change. Some mutations make it harder for viruses to spread, even in the air. Scientists found that combining a virus‚Äôs spike gene (which helps it spread) with a non-spike gene from an older virus makes it more contagious. This shows viruses use different strategies to stay airborne, and knowing how much virus they release can help predict how dangerous new variants might be.


Abstract

SARS-CoV-2 variants evolve to balance immune evasion and airborne transmission, yet the mechanisms remain unclear. In hamsters, first-wave, Alpha, and Delta variants transmitted efficiently via aerosols. Alpha emitted fewer viral particles than first-wave virus but compensated with a lower infectious dose (ID50). Delta exhibited higher airborne emission but required a higher ID50. A fall in airborne emission of infectious Delta virus over time after infection correlated with a decrease in its infectivity to RNA ratio in nasal wash and a decrease in contagiousness to sentinel animals. Omicron subvariants (BA.1, EG.5.1, BA.2.86, JN.1) displayed varying levels of airborne transmissibility, partially correlated with airborne emissions. Mutations in the non-spike genes contributed to reduced airborne transmissibility, since recombinant viruses with spike genes of BA.1 or JN.1 and non-spike genes from first-wave virus are more efficiently transmitted between hamsters. These findings reveal distinct viral strategies for maintaining airborne transmission. Early assessment of ID50 and aerosolized viral load may help predict transmissibility of emerging variants.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s44298-025-00120-1

Abstract

Long coronavirus disease (COVID) is a heterogeneous clinical condition of uncertain etiology triggered by infection with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Here we used ultrasensitive approaches to profile the immune system and the plasma proteome in healthy convalescent individuals and individuals with long COVID, spanning geographically independent cohorts from Sweden and the United Kingdom. Symptomatic disease was not consistently associated with quantitative differences in immune cell lineage composition or antiviral T cell immunity. Healthy convalescent individuals nonetheless exhibited higher titers of neutralizing antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 than individuals with long COVID, and extensive phenotypic analyses revealed a subtle increase in the expression of some co-inhibitory receptors, most notably PD-1 and TIM-3, among SARS-CoV-2 nonspike-specific CD8+T cells in individuals with long COVID. We further identified a shared plasma biomarker signature of disease linking breathlessness with apoptotic inflammatory networks centered on various proteins, including CCL3, CD40, IKBKG, IL-18 and IRAK1, and dysregulated pathways associated with cell cycle progression, lung injury and platelet activation, which could potentially inform the diagnosis and treatment of long COVID.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41590-025-02135-5

Title

Molecular dynamics simulation and docking studies reveals inhibition of NF-kB signaling as a promising therapeutic drug target for reduction in cytokines storms


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, let's tackle this. The user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. First, I need to understand the original content. The abstract talks about NF-kB and cytokine storms in COVID-19. NF-kB is involved in inflammation and cell death. Cytokines cause a storm that leads to severe illness. The paper is looking at small molecule inhibitors to stop this. They used docking and molecular dynamics to find a compound called NF30 with high binding affinity. The goal is to reduce severe cases of COVID-19. Now, simplifying this. The key points are: NF-kB role in inflammation, cytokine storm causing diseases, the study's aim to find inhibitors, the methods (virtual screening, AI), the compound NF30's effectiveness, and the potential for new drugs. Maybe start by stating that NF-kB is involved in inflammation and disease. Then explain cytokine storm and how the study is trying to stop it. Mention the methods used, the compound found, and its potential impact. Check if the user wants any specific details, but since they said brevity and clarity, keep it short. Avoid any markdown. Make sure the main idea is clear without jargon. NF-kB is a key player in inflammation and immune responses, but it can cause harmful overflows of cytokines, leading to severe illnesses like COVID-19. Researchers studied how to stop this by finding small molecules that block NF-kB, aiming to reduce deadly side effects. They used computer models to screen chemicals and found a compound, NF30, that binds strongly to NF-kB, offering hope for treating severe cases of the virus.


Abstract

Nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kB) plays a crucial role in numerous cellular processes, such as inflammation, immunological responses to infection, cell division, apoptosis, and the development of embryos and neurons. Cytokines, plays an important role in positive feedback loop and leads to inflammatory cell death through the release of pathogenic cytokine known to be cytokine storm which causes diseases like Acute Respiratory Disorder (ARD), multi-organ disorder, Hyperinflammation syndrome and may cause death. This cytochrome storm was identified in the people severely affected by covid-19. NF-kB presents a promising therapeutic opportunity to mitigate covid-19-induced cytokine storm and reduce the risk of severe morbidity and mortality resulting from the diseases. This paper therefore explores the modulation of the NF-kB pathway by inhibiting the binding of the transcription factor as a potential strategy to mitigate the morbidity and mortality caused by cytokine storms. To identify small molecule inhibitors of NF-kB signaling, we screened approximately 101 molecules in two identified pockets of NF-kB (p50/p65)-DNA complex. Each molecule was virtually screened in two pockets (A1 and A2). The focus library was developed starting from chemical structures obtained from the literature (Angelicin and Psolaren) which shows the inhibition of NF-kB signaling, as well as using artificial intelligence (WADDAICA) and rationally designed molecules. Among the 3 highest-scored ligands (NFAI64, NF30 and NF49) selected from the docking studies and further molecular dynamic investigations. The identified compound NF30 showed significantly higher binding affinity (ŒîGbinding) in A2 pocket (60.92‚Äâ¬±‚Äâ1.83¬†kJ/mol) as compared to the rest of the molecules, making it a promising molecule for the inhibition of NF-kB. The discovered novel compounds by computational studies could be of relevance to identify more potent inhibitors of NF-kB dependent biological functions beneficial to control the cytokine storm occurring in the patients affected with Covid-19.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-78411-5

Title

Abstract

This test-negative case-control study within the US Veterans Affairs Healthcare System aims to estimate early vaccine effectiveness (VE) of the BNT162b2 KP.2 vaccine (2024‚Äì2025 formulation) compared to not receiving the KP.2 vaccine against COVID-19 outcomes. The study includes adult patients (age¬†‚â•18 years) with an acute respiratory infection (ARI) in hospital, emergency department and urgent care (ED/UC), or outpatient settings between September 5 and November 30, 2024. Separate multivariable logistic regression models compare the odds of receiving BNT162b2 KP.2 vaccine among SARS-CoV-2 positive cases and test-negative controls within each ARI outcome category, while adjusting for potentially confounding variables. Among 44,598 ARI episodes, VE is 68% (42‚Äì82%), 57% (46‚Äì65%), and 56% (36‚Äì69%) against COVID-19-associated hospitalizations, emergency department and urgent care visits, and outpatient visits, respectively. Uptake of updated COVID-19 vaccines is low (3.7%).

Title

Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on admissions of deceased to an institute of legal medicine in Germany


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, let's tackle this. The user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. First, I need to understand the original content. The study looks at how the pandemic affected deaths in a German institute. They used stats to separate trends from the pandemic's impact. They found that people who died at home or in care facilities had more admissions, especially with SARS-CoV-2. Poverty didn't affect admissions before the pandemic, but during the pandemic, it did. Also, there was a rise in non-autopsy admissions during the pandemic. The doctors' reluctance to do house calls led to more deaths without criminological clues. Now, simplifying this. The key points are: pandemic caused more deaths at home and care facilities, especially with positive cases. Poverty didn't matter before, but during the pandemic, it did. More non-autopsy admissions during the pandemic. Doctors didn't do house calls, leading to more deaths without evidence. I need to make sure it's clear and concise. Avoid technical terms. Use simple language. Maybe start with the main finding: pandemic increased deaths at home and care facilities. Mention SARS-CoV-2, poverty's role, and the doctors' behavior. Also, the non-autopsy admissions and the lack of criminological clues. Keep it brief, no markdown. The pandemic caused more people to be admitted to a hospital for deaths, especially those who died at home or in care facilities. This happened because many had SARS-CoV-2 infections, and poverty didn‚Äôt seem to affect the likelihood of being admitted before the pandemic. During the pandemic, poverty did make people more likely to be admitted in those categories. Also, fewer autopsies were done during the pandemic, and doctors were less likely to visit homes to certify deaths, leading to more unexplained deaths without criminological clues.


Abstract

All over the world, the COVID-19 pandemic has impacted mortality beyond deaths that can be directly attributed to the viral disease. This study investigates the effects of the pandemic on admissions of deceased to a large institute of legal medicine and metropolitan morgue in Germany. Employing statistical models, the general time trend was separated from the effect of the pandemic in terms of place of death, autopsy category, age and sex. In addition, the pandemic‚Äôs impact on one of the structurally most important public health determinants, poverty, on numbers of admissions in different place of death categories was analyzed.¬†We find that the pandemic has caused a significant increase in admissions of those who died at residential addresses, which appears to be primarily driven by SARS-CoV-2 negative cases, and those who died in retirement and care facilities, with a significant overrepresentation of SARS-CoV-2 positive cases. A high degree of poverty in a neighborhood does not impact the likelihood to be admitted to the institute in those two categories before or during the pandemic. For dead bodies found in public spaces, however, a poverty variable causes a significant increase in the number of admissions during the pre-pandemic phase. Interestingly, this effect is reversed during the pandemic period.¬†The number of admissions without an autopsy being ordered or requested increased significantly during the pandemic. Further, the COVID-19 pandemic caused a significant increase in admissions in the senile population. Our results indicate that the reluctance of treating physicians to conduct house calls to certify a death has persisted throughout the pandemic and has caused a surge of admissions of deceased to the institute of legal medicine without any criminological indications or subsequent rise in forensic autopsy orders.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-97117-w

Title

Microfluidic nanobubbles produced using a micromixer for ultrasound imaging and gene delivery


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, the user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. Let me start by reading the original abstract carefully. The main points are about using ultrasound (US) to deliver drugs, genes, and nucleic acids. They mention microbubble (MB) or nanobubble (NB) technology, which are used as contrast agents. The study uses a microfluidic device to create these bubbles, which are responsive to ultrasound. The benefits include better imaging, targeted delivery, and effectiveness in different tissues. The results show that these NBs are efficient and can be used in gene delivery. I need to make sure the key terms are explained. Words like "ultrasound-mediated delivery," "tissue-specific targeting," "microfluidic technology," and "gene delivery" should be simplified. Avoid technical jargon. Maybe use analogies, like comparing the microfluidic device to a machine that makes bubbles quickly. Check the structure: the original starts with the safety of US delivery, then the role of microbubbles, the method used, the results, and the conclusion. Simplify each part without losing the original meaning. Avoid any markdown, keep it in plain text. Keep sentences short. Make sure the flow is clear for a young person. Let me piece it together step by step. Ultrasound (US) helps deliver drugs, genes, or DNA to specific areas in the body. Microbubbles (MBs) or nanobubbles (NBs) act as "smart" bubbles that respond to US waves. A special device makes these bubbles quickly and evenly, which helps US imaging and gene delivery. These bubbles are safe and work well in various tissues like muscles, heart, kidneys, or brain. The study shows they spread far after being injected and are effective for targeting areas exposed to US. This makes them useful for treatments using US.


Abstract

Ultrasound (US)-mediated delivery is considered relatively safe and achieves tissue-specific targeting by simply adjusting the application site of the physical energy. Moreover, combining US with micro- or nanobubbles (MBs or NBs), which serve as US contrast agents, enhances the delivery of drugs, genes, and nucleic acids which also functioning as a tool for US. The performance of US-responsive MBs and NBs, including their therapeutic outcomes, is influenced by the bubble manufacturing methods. Furthermore, productivity and scalability must also be considered for clinical applications. Among various NBs fabrication techniques, microfluidic technology has emerged as a promising approach. However, the potential of NBs generated by microfluidics for drug delivery remains unexplored. In this study, US-responsive NBs were prepared using a microfluidic device, providing a single step gas-filling operation and rapid production method not only for US imaging but also for gene delivery. The effectiveness of these NBs was subsequently evaluated. The preparation conditions for the microfluidic NBs (MF-NBs) were optimized based on their physical properties, including particle size, number concentration, and their performance as US agents. Gene delivery capability was assessed in various tissues, including muscles, heart, kidney, and brain. The results demonstrated that MF-NBs exhibit high monodispersity, enhance US imaging, achieve widespread distribution following administration (including in brain tissue), and enable gene delivery to irradiated areas. These findings suggest that MF-NBs, with their high productivity and uniformity, are promising candidates for practical applications in US imaging, gene delivery, and nucleic acid delivery systems.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-99171-w

Title

Non-human primate seasonal transcriptome atlas reveals seasonal changes in physiology and diseases


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, the user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. Let me read through the original text again. The main points are that animal systems like metabolism, immunity, and endocrine change seasonally, especially in winter. There's more disease morbidity and higher mortality in winter. But the exact mechanisms aren't known. They studied 80 tissues from rhesus macaques over a year, found seasonal changes in metabolites and hormones. Sex differences in SOGs (seasonally oscillating genes) were found. They created a database called NHPSTA. They used gene regulation studies to show GA-binding protein (GABP) regulates SOGs. Also, disease risk genes and drug interactions show seasonal changes. The database helps understand seasonal physiology and targets for seasonal diseases. Now, I need to make this clear and concise for a young person. Avoid jargon, keep it simple. Let me break it down: Start by stating the seasonal changes in systems. Mention the study of 80 tissues and the database. Then the findings: seasonal metabolites and hormones, sex differences in SOGs, GABP regulation. Also, the database's purpose. Make sure to keep it brief and not use complex terms. Check for clarity and ensure all key points are there without being too technical. Animals, including humans, have systems like metabolism, the immune, and endocrine that change seasonally. Winter is worse for diseases and deaths, but why? Researchers studied 80 tissues from rhesus macaques over a year, finding seasonal changes in what‚Äôs in blood and hormones. They found that certain genes (SOGs) change with the seasons and differ between males and females. These genes are linked to diseases and drugs. A new database shows how these genes work, helping understand how the body changes with the seasons and how to treat related illnesses.


Abstract

The metabolic, immune, and endocrine systems show profound seasonal changes in animals, including humans. In addition, morbidity from cardiovascular and psychiatric diseases is more severe and mortality rate is higher in winter. However, their molecular mechanisms remain unknown. Here we report the seasonal transcriptome of 80 tissues collected over 1 year from male and female rhesus macaques kept in a semi-natural outdoor environment. We find seasonal changes in plasma metabolites and hormones. Transcriptome analysis identifies sex differences in seasonally oscillating genes (SOGs) in all tissues studied, and we generate the web database ‚ÄòNon-Human Primate Seasonal Transcriptome Atlas (NHPSTA).‚Äô Transcriptional regulatory network analysis, siRNA knockdown, and mutant mouse analyses reveal regulation of SOGs by GA-binding protein (GABP). We also demonstrate seasonal oscillations in the expression of disease risk factor genes and drug interacting genes. NHPSTA provides a molecular resource for seasonally regulated physiology and targets for therapeutic interventions for seasonally regulated diseases.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-57994-1

Title

Disproportionality analysis of European safety reports on autoimmune and rheumatic diseases following COVID-19 vaccination


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, let's tackle this. The user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. First, I need to understand the original content. The study looks at how COVID-19 vaccines might be linked to autoimmune diseases. They checked safety reports from the EU's EV database. They found that some vaccines, like tozinameran, are linked to these conditions. Most AEFIs are serious, but some are unresolved. The most common conditions are immune-related, and the analysis suggests mRNA vaccines might be more linked to new autoimmune diseases. ChAd (a type of vaccine) has some links, but not as strong as mRNA. They mention under-reporting of autoimmune diseases after vaccination and suggest more research. Now, simplifying this for a young person. Avoid jargon, keep it clear. Maybe start with the main points: vaccines are safe, but some people get autoimmune issues after getting them. They analyzed reports, found some links to certain vaccines, most AEFIs are serious but not all resolved. Common conditions include arthritis, vasculitis, etc. mRNA vaccines might be more linked to new autoimmune diseases. ChAd has some links but less than mRNA. Under-reporting is a problem, so more research needed. Check if I missed anything. The key points are the study's purpose, the data collected, the findings about which vaccines are linked to autoimmune diseases, the severity of AEFIs, the most common conditions, and the need for more research. Make sure to keep it concise, no markdown, and avoid any comments. A study looked at how COVID-19 vaccines might be linked to autoimmune diseases. They checked safety reports from the EU‚Äôs EV database and found that some vaccines, like tozinameran, are linked to these conditions. Most reports of side effects were serious, but many weren‚Äôt fully resolved. The most common issues were arthritis, vasculitis, and other immune-related problems. The study suggests that mRNA vaccines may be more likely to cause new autoimmune diseases. ChAd vaccines had some links, but not as strong as mRNA. It also warns that autoimmune diseases might be under-reported after vaccination, so more research is needed to understand why.


Abstract

The safety profile of COVID-19 vaccines is well-established, yet the widespread immunization campaign has led to an increase in reported cases of Immune-Mediated and Rheumatic Diseases (IMDRs). This study aimed to assess the reporting of Adverse Events Following Immunization (AEFIs) related to IMDRs after COVID-19 vaccination. We analyzed all individual case safety reports (ICSRs) related to COVID-19 vaccines authorized in the European Union (i.e., tozinameran, elasomeran, ChAdOx1-S NCoV-19, and Ad26.Cov2.S) registered in the EudraVigilance (EV) database from January 1, 2021, to October 23, 2023. Our analysis identified ICSRs with events indicative of IMDRs and conducted disproportionality analysis (i.e., Reporting Odds Ratio (ROR) with 95% CI) to examine the frequency of different IMDR types linked to each vaccine. In total, 45,352 ICSRs reported at least one AEFI associated with rheumatic or autoimmune conditions, with 54% of them implicating tozinameran as the suspected vaccine. More than half of the reported AEFIs were classified as serious, with approximately 45% remaining unresolved. The most frequently reported conditions were other immune-mediated diseases, followed by arthritis, vasculitis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and tendinopathies. Our disproportionality analysis suggested that mRNA vaccines may be more frequently associated with new autoimmune rheumatic diseases. Stratified analysis revealed significant associations for ChAd, particularly in vasculitis and tendinopathies, only when compared to Ad26.Cov2.S. Real-world pharmacovigilance data suggest that autoimmune and rheumatic diseases may be under-reported following COVID-19 vaccination, highlighting the need for further research to better understand the underlying mechanisms. The findings from this disproportionality analysis suggest the need for further studies to investigate these results in greater depth.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-98313-4

Title

Targeted protein degraders of SARS-CoV-2 Mpro are more active than enzymatic inhibition alone with activity against nirmatrelvir resistant virus


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, let's tackle this. The user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. First, I need to understand the original content. The study is about using degraders, which are drugs that break down proteins, to make better antiviral drugs against SARS-CoV-2. They tested nirmatrelvir, an inhibitor, and made degraders that can target the enzyme Mpro. The results show these degraders are more effective against both normal and resistant viruses. So, the key points are: degraders can overcome resistance, they're made from existing inhibitors, and they work better than regular inhibitors. The user wants this simplified without any quotes and in clear, concise terms. I need to avoid technical jargon and make it relatable. Maybe start by stating the problem (no good antivirals), then the solution (degraders), how they work, results, and the conclusion. Keep each part short and use simple words. Check that all main points are covered: degraders vs. regular inhibitors, effectiveness against resistant viruses, the three compounds, and the conclusion about future therapies. Make sure not to add any extra info and keep it brevity-focused. A study shows that making drugs that break down viral proteins (degraders) can help fight viruses better, even when the virus becomes resistant. Researchers adapted an existing drug, nirmatrelvir, into degraders that target the enzyme Mpro. These degraders work more effectively than regular inhibitors, even against resistant virus strains. The results suggest degraders could become stronger antiviral treatments, offering hope for future therapies.


Abstract

BackgroundEffective antiviral therapy is lacking for most viral infections, and when available, is frequently compromised by the selection of resistance. Targeted protein degraders could provide an avenue to more effective antivirals, able to overcome the selection of resistance. The aim of this study was to determine whether adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 main protease (Mpro, also described as chymotrypsin-like protease (3CLpro) or non-structural protein 5 (Nsp5)) inhibitors into degraders leads to increased antiviral activity, including activity against resistant virus.MethodsWe adapted the clinically approved Mpro inhibitor nirmatrelvir into a panel of degraders. Size-matched non-degrading controls were also synthesised to discriminate degradation activity from inhibition activity. Degrader activity was confirmed using an inducible Mpro-HiBiT tag expressing cell line. Antiviral activity against both wildtype and nirmatrelvir-resistant virus was performed using infection of susceptible cell lines.ResultsHere we show three compounds, derived from nirmatrelvir and utilising VHL or IAP ubiquitin ligase recruiters, capable of degrading Mpro protein in a concentration, time and proteasome dependent fashion. These compounds also degrade nirmatrelvir-resistant mutant Mpro. The most potent of these compounds possesses enhanced antiviral activity against multiple wildtype SARS-CoV-2 strains and nirmatrelvir-resistant strains compared to non-degrading controls.ConclusionsThis work demonstrates the feasibility of generating degraders from viral protein inhibitors, and confirms that degraders possess higher antiviral potency and activity against resistant virus, compared to size matched non-degrading enzymatic inhibitors. These findings further support the development of targeted viral protein degraders as antiviral drugs, which may lead to more effective antiviral therapies for the future.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s43856-025-00863-1

That's concise, uses simple terms, and keeps the original meaning. Let me check if it's brief and clear. Yes, it's under 20 words, uses everyday language, and captures all the key points without any technical jargon. A microbial mix boosts Th1 immunity and helps fight LCMV but worsens the disease.

Title

A specific microbial consortium enhances Th1 immunity, improves LCMV viral clearance but aggravates LCMV disease pathology in mice


ü§ñ Abstract

The main idea is that the gut microbiome (specifically OMM12) affects how the immune system responds to a virus called LCMV. In germ-free mice, which don't have any microbes, the immune response is weaker compared to mice with the microbiome (SPF mice). When they introduce OMM12, the immune response is more effective, leading to more severe disease but also better virus clearance. The immune system's ability to fight viruses can vary greatly between people, but scientists aren‚Äôt sure why. When mice are given a special bacterial community (OMM12), their immune system responds better to a virus called LCMV. Compared to mice without any microbes (SPF), OMM12 mice have stronger immune responses, leading to more severe disease but also better virus clearance. Studies show that the immune cells in OMM12 mice are more active in fighting the virus, suggesting the gut microbiome plays a key role in shaping how the body fights infections. This research could help develop better vaccines and treatments.


Abstract

Anti-viral immunity can vary tremendously from individual to individual but mechanistic understanding is still scarce. Here, we show that a defined, low complex bacterial community (OMM12) but not the general absence of microbes in germ-free mice leads to a more potent immune response compared to the microbiome of specific-pathogen-free (SPF) mice after a systemic viral infection with LCMV Clone-13. Consequently, gnotobiotic mice colonized with OMM12have more severe LCMV-induced disease pathology but also enhance viral clearance in the intestinal tract. Mechanistically, single-cell RNA sequencing analysis of adoptively transferred virus-specific T helper cells and endogenous T helper cells in the intestinal tract reveal a stronger pro-inflammatory Th1 profile and a more vigorous expansion in OMM12than SPF mice. Altogether, our work highlights the causative function of the intestinal microbiome for shaping adaptive anti-viral immunity with implications for vaccination strategies and anti-cancer treatment regimens.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-59073-x

Title

Mixed methods study of views and experience of non-hospitalised individuals with long COVID of using pacing interventions


ü§ñ Abstract

Okay, let's tackle this. The user wants me to simplify the abstract for a young person. First, I need to understand the original content. The abstract talks about Long COVID, its symptoms, pacing as a strategy, a study on participants' experiences, and the findings. Results showed pacing helped with motivation and planning, but there were challenges like time and complexity. The study says pacing might work but more research is needed. The potential for improving symptom management and rehab strategies. Now, simplifying for a young person. Avoid jargon, keep it clear. Make sure to retain the original meaning. Avoid quotes, keep it concise. Let me break it down: Start with the main idea: Long COVID is a lot of people's problem, with symptoms like tiredness and brain fog. Pacing is a way to manage it by slowing down, which could help. The study looked at people who didn't go to the hospital. They used a survey and interviews. People thought pacing helped them, but there were problems like time and instructions. So, it's possible but more research is needed. Also, the feasibility questionnaire and interviews. But the user wants it concise. Maybe not mention the trial name. Keep it simple. Check for any technical terms. "Reflexive thematic analysis" is too complex. Just say "interviews were analyzed using a method." Okay. Make sure the answer is in one paragraph, clear, and concise. Long COVID is a common condition that causes fatigue, breathlessness, and confusion. Pacing is a way to save energy by slowing down, which helps people manage their symptoms. A study looked at how people with Long COVID felt about using pacing. They used a survey and interviews, finding that pacing helped with motivation and planning but had challenges like time and complexity. It may work, but more research is needed to prove its benefits. The study suggests pacing could help manage symptoms and support recovery for people with Long COVID.


Abstract

Long COVID is highly prevalent and debilitating, with key symptoms including fatigue, breathlessness, and brain fog. Pacing is an approach to energy conservation used to help people with chronic conditions like ME/CFS manage the impact of their condition, and could be a useful strategy for people with Long COVID. The aim of this study was to explore the views and experiences of non-hospitalised adults with Long COVID of pacing as an intervention. This mixed methods study is part of the Therapies for Long COVID (TLC) Feasibility trial. A feasibility questionnaire was developed for participants. In addition, semi-structured interviews were conducted with a sub-sample of participants at the end of the study and these interviews were analysed using the reflexive thematic analysis approach. 28 participants completed the feasibility questionnaire and 19 participants took part in a qualitative interview. Participants found that pacing helped improve motivation and activity planning. Concerns included challenges due to time constraints, complexity of the intervention, and limited instructions. Pacing for Long COVID may offer potential benefits and is feasible but further research is required to demonstrate its benefits. Overall, research on pacing in the context of Long COVID has the potential to enhance our understanding of symptom management and rehabilitation strategies for this emerging population.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-96319-6



2025-04-17 ü§ñ Impact of COVID-19 on Umbilical Cord Blood Transplantation in Japan

Title

The impact of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic on umbilical cord blood transplantation in Japan: insights from an interrupted time series analysis


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version of the abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic affected how people in Japan got transplants, especially those using special blood cells called cord blood. Researchers looked at data from 2011 to 2021 and found that cord blood transplants increased significantly after the pandemic started, while bone marrow transplants decreased. This meant that more people were relying on cord blood transplants instead of other options, which helped keep transplant activity going during a time when it could have stopped.


Abstract

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic disrupted healthcare systems worldwide, particularly affecting hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) activities. Understanding the impact of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic on transplant practices, especially in Japan, where cord blood transplantation (CBT) is prevalent, is crucial. A total of 40,444 allogeneic HSCT cases in Japan between 2011 and 2021 were examined using an interrupted time series analysis to assess the impact of COVID-19 on CBT utilization. Following the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, CBT cases demonstrated a significant increase (11.06 [95% confidence interval (CI): 1.87 to 20.25] cases per month), whereas bone marrow transplantation cases decreased, by 10.74 cases per month (95% CI, ‚àí19.84 to ‚àí1.63 cases per month). Total HSCT cases remained stable with a level change of 5.47 cases per month (95% CI, ‚àí10.07 to 21.01 cases per month) and a trend change of ‚àí1.11 cases per month (95% CI, ‚àí2.22 to 0.004 cases per month). The interrupted time series analysis showed significantly increased CBT cases in Japan, highlighting its crucial role as an alternative transplant source during the pandemic. CBT offset the impact of the decrease in bone marrow transplantation and contributed to the maintenance of HSCT activity in Japan during the unprecedented crisis.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41409-025-02588-0



2025-04-17 ü§ñ COVID Vaccine Effectiveness in People Who Have Had or Been Exposed to COVID-19

Title

Functional T cell response to COVID-19 vaccination with or without natural infection with SARS-CoV-2 in adults and children


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version of the abstract: The immune system works differently in kids than it does in grown-ups. Scientists want to know how the vaccine for COVID-19 affects kids' immune systems compared to adults. They studied 51 kids and 45 grown-ups who got vaccinated or didn't get vaccinated, and some had already been infected with COVID-19. The study found that: * Kids had a weaker response to the vaccine than grown-ups * Grown-ups who hadn't been infected before vaccination had a stronger response to the vaccine than unvaccinated adults * Kids who had been infected before vaccination reacted differently to the vaccine * Some vaccines might work better for kids than others.


Abstract

Severe COVID-19 is rare in children suggesting differences in immune response between children and adults. Limited information is available on how cellular immunity is modulated by COVID-19 vaccination and prior infection, and whether it is differentially modulated in children compared to adults. Here, we aimed to compare COVID-19 vaccine-induced functional T cell response between adults and children with and without previous SARS-CoV-2 infection. Adults (18‚Äì45 years;n=‚Äâ45) and children (5‚Äì10 years;n=‚Äâ51;), who received Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine or remained unvaccinated, and previously infected or not with SARS-CoV-2 were selected from two cross-sectional SARS-CoV-2 serosurveillance studies conducted in Bangladesh. Plasma nucleocapsid (N)-specific antibodies were measured by electrochemiluminescence immunoassay; IFN-Œ≥, perforin and granzyme B secreting T cells were assessed using ELISpot assay. Vaccination in adults without previous infection, induced higher frequencies of IFN-Œ≥ and granzyme B secreting T lymphocytes compared to unvaccinated adults, while it increased only IFN-Œ≥ expression in vaccinated children. Previous infection increased IFN-Œ≥ response in unvaccinated adults only. Unvaccinated children showed higher granzyme B expression compared to adults irrespective of infection status. In vaccinated individuals, prior infection induced perforin expression in both adults and children. Children showed slightly different functional T cell response than adults in response to COVID-19 vaccination and infection. mRNA vaccination provided higher IFN-Œ≥ response in both adults and children, but induced cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) response in adults only. Future studies may evaluate the impact of other types of COVID-19 vaccines on functional T cell immunity in children to confirm the findings.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-95870-6



2025-04-17 ü§ñ Post Covid Health Compared to Mild Covid Infections

Title

Anti-nucleocapsid and anti-spike antibody trajectories in people with post-covid condition versus acute-only infections: a nested longitudinal case-control study within the Virus Watch prospective cohort


ü§ñ Abstract

Here is the rewritten abstract: People who got very sick from COVID-19 after being infected might have a different reaction to getting vaccinated than people who just got a mild version of the disease. We looked at how many people developed antibodies after their first COVID-19 infection, versus those who only had a mild case, and compared it to people who got vaccinated. We found that people who got PCC (a condition where people get sick after having COVID-19) are more likely to make certain antibodies after getting infected, but the vaccine doesn't seem to affect this.


Abstract

People with Post-Covid Condition (PCC) may demonstrate aberrant immune responses post-infection; however, serological follow-up studies are limited. We aim to compare SARS-CoV-2 serological responses to infection and vaccination in people who develop PCC versus those with an acute infection only. Participants (n=‚Äâ2010) are a sub-cohort of the Virus Watch community cohort in England who provided monthly finger-prick serological samples. We compare the likelihood of post-infection seroconversion using logistic mixed models and the trajectories of anti-nucleocapsid (anti-N) and anti-spike (anti-S) antibodies using linear mixed models. Participants who developed PCC (n=‚Äâ394) have 1.8x the odds of post-infection seroconversion for anti-N antibodies compared to those with an acute infection only (n=‚Äâ1616) (odds ratio= 1.81 (95% confidence interval (CI) 1.16-2.90); however, these results are moderated by vaccination status and variant ‚Äì with differences observed in pre-Omicron, unvaccinated participants. Anti-N levels, however, were elevated within 200 days post-infection in people with PCC compared to those without, after accounting for variant and vaccination status. Vaccination response (anti-S) pre- or post-infection did not systematically differ between groups. People with PCC demonstrate persistently higher anti-N antibody levels following primary infection compared to those with an acute infection only. These findings extend emerging evidence around infection-related immune activation and PCC.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58766-7



2025-04-17 ü§ñ Predictors of Death in Heart Disease Patients Who Had Covid-19

Title

Sex and other predictors of mortality in long-term follow-up of patients with cardiovascular disease and COVID-19: a single-center retrospective study


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a rewritten version of the abstract in simpler terms: Men are more likely to have a worse outcome if they get coronavirus than women. But we don't know much about what happens long after they're hospitalized. We looked at data from over 4000 people who were hospitalized with COVID-19 in Poland between 2020 and 2021. We found that men were younger, sicker, and more likely to have heart problems when they got COVID-19 compared to women. When we followed them up for almost 4 years, we saw that men were more likely to die. The scientists also found that if you're a man with certain health problems or markers in your blood, it could make it harder to survive long-term.


Abstract

Male sex is a well-known predictor of short-term prognosis in patients with coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Data, however, on long-term outcomes are scarce. We aimed to assess the differences in mortality between sexes and find other important predictors of survival from a long-term perspective. Data from all patients retrieved from a database of COVID-19 patients hospitalized at University Hospital in Krakow, Poland, between February 13, 2020, and May 10, 2021, were analyzed for clinical in-hospital data and after a 42¬†months follow-up period. Of the 4071 COVID-19 patients hospitalized, 2183 were men (53.6%). Males were on average younger and more likely to have concomitant chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, heart failure, coronary artery disease (including acute and chronic coronary syndrome) compared to women. In terms of laboratory findings, more advanced inflammatory markers and troponin I were predominantly observed in male patients than in female patients. Males were found to have a greater predisposition for relevant cardiovascular comorbidities and were more likely to have died during the 42¬†months follow-up. Additionally, higher levels of troponin I, N-terminal pro B-type natriuretic peptide and D-dimer were associated with a greater risk of death. Kaplan‚ÄìMeier survival analyses revealed a worse 42¬†months survival for men up to the age of 65¬†years. Cardiovascular comorbidities, male sex and older age, as well as higher concentrations of markers indicating a thrombotic state and myocardial injury, were associated with poorer long-term prognosis in patients with COVID-19.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-93402-w



2025-04-16 ü§ñ Impact of Long COVID Symptoms on Healthcare Use

Title

Dose‚Äìresponse effect between the number of long COVID symptoms and the use of different health services


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version: Researchers studied people in South Brazil who had COVID-19 for a long time (long COVID). They wanted to know how often these people used healthcare services after their symptoms went away. The study found that people with long COVID used more healthcare services than those without it. The type of symptoms they had also affected how much they used health services. For example, if someone had musculoskeletal (muscle) or neurological (nerve) problems, they were more likely to use primary care services. If they had respiratory (breathing) problems, they were more likely to use emergency services. The study suggests that healthcare in Brazil needs to be improved to help people with long COVID get the right treatment and care.


Abstract

This study aims to identify the use of health services by individuals with long COVID residing in South Brazil 6¬†months after the acute phase of a SARS-CoV-2 infection. A cross-sectional cohort study of individuals who survived coronavirus disease was conducted in Rio Grande, Brazil. The participants were asked about their use of health services during the 6‚Äì10¬†months following recovery from SARS-CoV-2 infection. Data on the overall use of primary healthcare services, general practitioner services, emergency services, specialist doctors‚Äô services, and specialized services were collected. Individuals with long COVID reported more frequent use of primary healthcare services, emergency services, specialist doctors‚Äô services, and specialized services than those without long COVID. The musculoskeletal, neurological, and respiratory symptoms of long COVID were associated with frequent use of primary healthcare services, whereas the neurological, digestive, and respiratory symptoms were associated with frequent use of emergency services. Finally, the use of specialist doctors‚Äô services and specialized services was more frequent in participants with neurological symptoms than in those without these symptoms. Individuals with long COVID used more healthcare services than those without long COVID in South Brazil. Participants with a greater number of symptoms used more health services than those with fewer symptoms. Healthcare services use depends on the type of the long COVID symptoms. Health services in Brazil need to be reorganized and adapted to provide adequate treatment and care to people with long COVID.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-72263-9



2025-04-16 ü§ñ How mRNA Vaccines Work Better with a Special Gene

Title

Re-adenylation by TENT5A enhances efficacy of SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version: Scientists studied how mRNA vaccines work in the body. They used a special tool to look at the tiny instructions (mRNA) inside these vaccines. They found that some vaccines have really long instructions attached to them, and this helps them stay stable in the body. But other vaccines don't have as many instructions, which makes them less stable. The scientists also discovered that there's an enzyme called TENT5A that helps make the instructions more stable. They think that if we can find ways to use TENT5A better, it could make mRNA vaccines work even better for people.


Abstract

Despite the widespread use of mRNA vaccines against COVID-19, little is known about the metabolism of therapeutic RNAs. Here we use nanopore sequencing1,2,3to analyse individual therapeutic mRNA molecules, focusing on their poly(A) tails. We show that the Moderna mRNA-1273 vaccine4has a poly(A) tail of around 100 nucleotides, followed by an mŒ®CmŒ®AG sequence. In cell lines, mRNA-1273 undergoes rapid degradation initiated by mŒ®CmŒ®AG removal, followed by CCR4‚ÄìNOT-mediated deadenylation. However, in medically relevant preclinical models, particularly in macrophages, mRNA-1273 poly(A) tails are extended to up to 200 nucleotides by the TENT5A poly(A) polymerase5,6,7, which is induced by the vaccine. Re-adenylation, which stabilizes target mRNAs, is consistently observed in synthetic mRNAs that encode proteins targeted to the endoplasmic reticulum, such as ovalbumin or antigens from Zika virus8or the malaria parasite9. The extent of re-adenylation varies: the BioNTech‚ÄìPfizer BNT162b2 vaccine10shows less potent re-adenylation than mRNA-1273, which correlates with a smaller proportion of membrane-associated BNT162b2. This highlights the crucial role of spatial accessibility to ER-resident TENT5A in determining re-adenylation efficiency. In vivo, TENT5A is expressed in immune cells that take up mRNA vaccine, and TENT5A deficiency reduces specific immunoglobulin production for mRNA vaccines after immunization in mice. Overall, our findings reveal a principle for enhancing the efficacy of therapeutic mRNAs, paving the way for improvement.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-08842-1



2025-04-16 ü§ñ Improved title: Lipid Delivery System for Lung mRNA

Title

Multicomponent thiolactone-based ionizable lipid screening platform for efficient and tunable mRNA delivery to the lungs


ü§ñ Abstract

Here is an abstract rewritten for a young person: Scientists are working on making tiny particles called lipid nanoparticles that can carry genetic material into cells. They want to make these particles better so they can deliver genes more efficiently and target specific organs. To do this, they created a new way to test different lipids in one step, which helped them discover 91 new types of lipids that work well together. One of these lipids, called CP-LC-0729, is really good at delivering genes into cells without causing harm. It's like a special delivery system for our bodies!


Abstract

Ionizable lipids are essential components of lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) for efficient mRNA delivery. However, designing them for high protein expression, endosomal escape, and organ targeting is challenging due to complex structure-activity relationships. Here, we present a high-throughput platform for screening ionizable lipids using a two-step, scalable, one-pot reaction. This enabled the synthesis andvivoscreening of 91 new lipids, followed by a structure-activity study, leading to the development of CP-LC-0729, which significantly surpasses the MC3 benchmark in protein expression with preliminary studies showing no in vivo toxicity. Additionally, a one-step strategy helped to yield a permanently cationic lipid which was tested in a fifth-lipid formulation, showing a highly selective lung delivery with a 32-fold increase in protein expression in vivo, outperforming current endogenous targeting strategies. All these findings underscore the potential of lipid CP-LC-0729 and our lipid platform in advancing the efficiency and specificity of mRNA delivery systems.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s42004-025-01516-z



2025-04-15 ü§ñ Outpatient Experimental Infection to Develop Affordable RSV Vaccine

Title

Risk analysis for outpatient experimental infection as a pathway for affordable RSV vaccine development


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version of the abstract: Scientists are working on new ways to test vaccines quickly, using controlled infections that mimic real-life cases. They want to do these tests in doctor's offices instead of hospitals to save money and make things easier for participants. They studied how well this approach worked with a virus called RSV (which causes respiratory problems) and found that it was safe and only had one transmission event. The study showed that doing vaccines in doctor's offices can be just as effective as doing them in hospitals, with some added benefits like being more convenient for participants. The researchers propose creating guidelines and safety measures to make this approach work better and faster for vaccine development.


Abstract

Controlled human infection models (CHIMs) are an important tool for accelerating clinical development of vaccines. CHIM costs are driven by quarantine facilities but may be reduced by performing CHIM in the outpatient setting. Furthermore, outpatient CHIMs offer benefits beyond costs, such as a participant-friendly approach and increased real-world aspect. We analyze safety, logistic and ethical risks of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) CHIM in the outpatient setting. A review of the literature identified outpatient CHIMs involving respiratory pathogens. RSV transmission risk was assessed using data from our inpatient and outpatient RSV CHIMs (EudraCT 020-004137-21). Fifty-nine outpatient CHIMs using RSV,Streptococcus pneumoniae, rhinovirus, and an ongoingBordetella Pertussisoutpatient CHIM were included. One transmission event was recorded. In an inpatient RSV CHIM, standard droplet and isolation measures were sufficient to limit RSV transmission and no symptomatic third-party transmission was measured in the first outpatient RSV CHIM. Logistic and ethical advantages support outpatient CHIM adoption. We propose a framework for outpatient RSV CHIM with risk mitigation strategies to enhance affordable vaccine development.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41541-025-01125-w



2025-04-15 ü§ñ How bacteria use a protein to fight off a type of attack from our immune system.

Title

Bacterial biofilm-derived H-NS protein acts as a defense against Neutrophil Extracellular Traps (NETs)


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version of the abstract: Bacteria make a special kind of DNA that lives outside their cells, called extracellular DNA (eDNA). As bacteria form colonies, this eDNA helps hold them together and makes it harder for other organisms to attack. Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that can trap and kill bacteria with the help of eDNA. However, some protein called H-NS can stop neutrophils from doing their job by disabling their ability to form traps and killing free-living bacteria. This makes H-NS a potential target for new treatments to control diseases caused by NETs.


Abstract

Extracellular DNA (eDNA) is crucial for the structural integrity of bacterial biofilms as they undergo transformation from B-DNA to Z-DNA as the biofilm matures. This transition to Z-DNA increases biofilm rigidity and prevents binding by canonical B-DNA-binding proteins, including nucleases. One of the primary defenses against bacterial infections are Neutrophil Extracellular Traps (NETs), wherein neutrophils release their own eDNA to trap and kill bacteria. Here we show that H-NS, a bacterial nucleoid associated protein (NAP) that is also released during biofilm development, is able to incapacitate NETs. Indeed, when exposed to human derived neutrophils, H-NS prevented the formation of NETs and lead to NET eDNA retraction in previously formed NETs. NETs that were exposed to H-NS also lost their ability to kill free-living bacteria which made H-NS an attractive therapeutic candidate for the control of NET-related human diseases. A model of H-NS release from biofilms and NET incapacitation is discussed.

Article URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41522-025-00691-0



2025-04-15 ü§ñ The impact of health issues on people's interactions with others in Belgium from 2022-2023.

Title

The role of frailty in shaping social contact patterns in Belgium, 2022‚Äì2023


ü§ñ Abstract

Here's a simplified version of the abstract: Infectious diseases spread when people with respiratory problems come into contact with others.
